header_summary:
Ethan Heilman introduced a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) featuring a new opcode, FOLDFUNCTIONSTREAM, to address computational and safety challenges in Bitcoin script execution, aiming to enhance script functionality without risking memory growth. This proposal, which includes functions like SHA256 and FACTORS for various computational tasks, suggests activation via the "versionbits" BIP9 method and discusses deployment timelines and potential concerns around argument order and undefined behavior handling. For more details, a [GitHub pull request](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/XXX) is available for reference.

Antoine Riard analyzed the implications of current BIP implementation on transaction relay protocols, suggesting a more inclusive upgrade process to accommodate non-upgraded peers and proposing a division of the BIP into two for better modularity and implementation. This includes enhancing transaction relay reliability, with links to proposed changes on signaling and transaction processing mechanisms available at [Signaling mechanism proposal](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1663) and [Transaction message processing mechanism proposal](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1664), respectively.

Jaswanth, a computer science student, is developing a solution to mitigate Fork After Withholding (FAW) attacks in mining pools by tracking miners' reputations based on their Proof of Partial Work (PPoW) submissions. Recognizing the need for practical implementation guidance, he seeks simulation tools and references a study from the ACM Digital Library for further insight on the topic, available [here](https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3133956.3134019).

Lastly, the discussion by t-bast emphasizes the importance of using a unique `invreq_payer_id` for each contact to bolster privacy and security through domain separation, highlighting the critical role of safeguarding data integrity in cryptographic practices. Further information on this topic can be found [here](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/bolt-12-trusted-contacts/1046/7).

today_in_history_posts.title: Timelocks and Lightning on MimbleWimble
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The post explores `nLockTime` in MimbleWimble for potential cross-system atomic swaps.
- It highlights MimbleWimble's inability to support Lightning due to no relative locktime.
- Lack of relative locktime in MimbleWimble hinders Lightning integration, not the absence of SCRIPT.

today_in_history_posts.title: Selling timestamps (via payment points and scalars + Pedersen commitments ) [try2]
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Konstantin Ketterer proposes a Bitcoin blockchain timestamp solution using a Pedersen commit.
- The solution allows for low-fee message timestamping via Merkle tree aggregation or higher costs for solitary messages.
- It shifts timestamping risk from buyer to seller, introducing a minor security assumption regarding the discrete logarithm.
